verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 1:1
verses.text: Concerning Repentance, Book II:  Chapter I.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 1:2
verses.text: St.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 1:3
verses.text: Ambrose gives additional rules concerning repentance, and shows that it must not be delayed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 1:5
verses.text: Although in the former book we have written many things which may tend to the more perfect practice of repentance, yet inasmuch as a great deal more may be added, we will continue the repast so as not to seem to have relinquished the provisions of our teaching only half consumed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 1:7
verses.text: For repentance must be taken in hand not only anxiously, but also quickly, lest perchance that father of the house in the Gospel who planted a fig-tree in his vineyard should come and seek fruit on it, and finding none, say to the vine-dresser: "Cut it down, why doth it cumber the ground?" And unless the vine-dresser should intercede and say: "Lord, let it alone this year also, until I dig about it and dung it, and if it bear fruitâ€”well; but if not let it be cut down".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 1:9
verses.text: Let us then dung this field which we possess, and imitate those hard-working farmers, who are not ashamed to satiate the land with rich dung and to scatter the grimy ashes over the field, that they may gather more abundant crops.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 1:11
verses.text: And the Apostle teaches us how to dung it, saying: "I count all things but dung, that I may gain Christ," and he, through evil report and good report, attained to pleasing Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 1:12
verses.text: For he had read that Abraham, when confessing himself to be but dust and ashes, in his deep humility found favour with God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 1:13
verses.text: He had read how Job, sitting among the ashes, regained all that he had lost.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 1:14
verses.text: He had heard in the utterance of David, how God "raiseth the poor out of the dust, and lifteth the needy out of the dunghill".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 1:16
verses.text: Let us then not be ashamed to confess our sins unto the Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 1:17
verses.text: Shame indeed there is when each makes known his sins, but that shame, as it were, ploughs his land, removes the ever-recurring brambles, prunes the thorns, and gives life to the fruits which he believed were dead.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 1:18
verses.text: Follow him who, by diligently ploughing his field, sought for eternal fruit: "Being reviled we bless, being persecuted we endure, being defamed we entreat, we are made as the offscouring of the world".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 1:19
verses.text: If you plough after this fashion you will sow spiritual seed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 1:20
verses.text: Plough that you may get rid of sin and gain fruit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 1:21
verses.text: He ploughed so as to destroy in himself the last tendency to persecution.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 1:22
verses.text: What more could Christ give to lead us on to the pursuit of perfection, than to convert and then give us for a teacher one who was a persecutor?.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:1
verses.text: Chapter II.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:2
verses.text: A passage quoted by the heretics against repentance is explained in two ways, the first being that Heb.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:3
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:4
verses.text: 4 refers to the impossibility of being baptized again; the second, that what is impossible with man is possible with God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:6
verses.text: Being then refuted by the clear example of the Apostle and by his writings, the heretics yet endeavour to resist further, and say that their opinion is supported by apostolic authority, bringing forward the passage in the Epistle to the Hebrews: "For it is impossible that those who were once enlightened, and have tasted the heavenly gift, and have been made partakers of the Holy Spirit, and have tasted the good word of God, and the powers of the world to come, should if they fall away be again renewed unto repentance, crucifying again the Son of God, and put Him to open shame".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:8
verses.text: Could Paul teach in opposition to his own act? He had at Corinth forgiven sin through penance, how could he himself speak against his own decision? Since, then, he could not destroy what he had built, we must assume that what he says was different from, but not contrary to, what had gone before.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:9
verses.text: For what is contrary is opposed to itself, what is different has ordinarily another meaning.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:10
verses.text: Things which are contrary are not such that one can support the other.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:11
verses.text: Inasmuch, then, as the Apostle spoke of remitting penance, he could not be silent as to those who thought that baptism was to be repeated.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:12
verses.text: And it was right first of all to remove our anxiety, and to let us know that even after baptism, if any sinned their sins  could be forgiven them, lest a false belief in a reiterated baptism should lead astray those who were destitute of all hope of forgiveness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:13
verses.text: And secondly, it was right to set forth in a well-reasoned argument that baptism is not to be repeated.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:15
verses.text: And that the writer was speaking of baptism is evident from the very words in which it is stated that it is impossible to renew unto repentance those who were fallen, inasmuch as we are renewed by means of the laver of baptism, whereby we are born again, as Paul says himself: "For we are buried with Him through baptism into death, that, like as Christ rose from the dead through the glory of the Father, so we, too, should walk in newness of life".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:16
verses.text: And in another place: "Be ye renewed in the spirit of your mind, and put on the new man which is created after God".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:17
verses.text: And elsewhere again: "Thy youth shall be renewed like the eagle," because the eagle after death is born again from its ashes, as we being dead in sin are through the Sacrament of Baptism born again to God, and created anew.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:18
verses.text: So, then, here as elsewhere, he teaches one baptism.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:19
verses.text: "One faith," he says, "one baptism".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:21
verses.text: This, too, is plain, that in him who is baptized the Son of God is crucified, for our flesh could not do away sin unless it were crucified in Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:22
verses.text: And then it is written that: "All we who were baptized into Jesus Christ were baptized into His death".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:23
verses.text: And farther on: "If we have been planted in the likeness of His death, we shall be also in the likeness of His resurrection, knowing that our old man was fastened with Him to His cross".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:24
verses.text: And to the Colossians he says: "Buried with Him by baptism, wherein ye also rose again with Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:25
verses.text: Which was written to the intent that we should believe that He is crucified in us, that our sins may be purged through Him, that He, Who alone can forgive sins, may nail to His cross the handwriting which was against us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:26
verses.text: In us He triumphs over principalities and powers, as it is written of Him: "He made a show of principalities and powers, triumphing over them in Himself".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:28
verses.text: So, then, that which he says in this Epistle to the Hebrews, that it is impossible for those who have fallen to be "renewed unto repentance, crucifying again the Son of God, and putting Him to open shame," must be considered as having reference to baptism, wherein we crucify the Son of God in ourselves, that the world may be by Him crucified for us, who triumph, as it were, when we take to ourselves the likeness of His death, who put to open shame upon His cross principalities and powers, and triumphed over them, that in the likeness of His death we, too, might triumph over the principalities whose yoke we throw off.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:29
verses.text: But Christ was crucified once, and died to sin once, and so there is but one, not several baptisms.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:31
verses.text: But what of the passage wherein the doctrine of baptisms is spoken of? Because under the Law there were many baptisms or washings, he rightly rebukes those who forsake what is perfect and seek again the first principles of the word.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:32
verses.text: He teaches us that the whole of the washings under the Law are done away with, and that there is one baptism in the sacraments of the Church.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:33
verses.text: But he exhorts us that leaving the first principles of the word we should go on to perfection.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:34
verses.text: "And this," he says, "we will do, if God permits," for no one can be perfect without the grace of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:36
verses.text: And indeed I might also say to any one who thought that this passage spoke of repentance, that things which are impossible with men are possible with God; and God is able whensoever He wills to forgive us our sins, even those which we think cannot be forgiven.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:37
verses.text: And so it is possible for God to give us that which it seems to us impossible to obtain.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:38
verses.text: For it seemed impossible that water should wash away sin, and Naaman the Syrian thought that his leprosy could not be cleansed by water.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:39
verses.text: But that which was impossible God made to be possible, Who gave us so great grace.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:40
verses.text: In like manner it seemed impossible that sins should be forgiven through repentance, but Christ gave this power to His apostles, which has been transmitted to the priestly office.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:41
verses.text: That, then, has become possible which was impossible.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 2:42
verses.text: But, by a true reasoning, he convinces us that the reiteration by any one of the Sacrament of Baptism is not permitted.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 3:1
verses.text: Chapter III.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 3:2
verses.text: Explanation of the parable of the Prodigal Son, in which St.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 3:3
verses.text: Ambrose applies it to refute the teaching of the Novatians, proving that reconciliation ought not to be refused to the greatest offender upon suitable proof of repentance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 3:5
verses.text: And the Apostle does not contradict  the plain teaching of Christ, Who set forth, as a comparison of a repentant sinner, one going to a foreign country after receiving all his substance from his father, wasted it in riotous living, and later, when feeding upon husks, longed for his father's bread and then gained the robe, the ring, the shoes, and the slaying of the calf, which is a likeness of the Passion of the Lord, whereby we receive forgiveness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 3:7
verses.text: Well is it said that he went into a foreign country who is cut off from the sacred altar, for this is to be separated from that Jerusalem which is in heaven, from the citizenship and home of the saints.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 3:8
verses.text: For which reason the Apostle says: "Therefore now ye are no more strangers and foreigners, but fellow-citizens with the saints and of the household of God".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 3:10
verses.text: "And," it is said, "wasted his substance".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 3:11
verses.text: Rightly, for he whose faith halts in bringing forth good works does consume it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 3:12
verses.text: For, "faith is the substance of things hoped for, the evidence of things not seen".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 3:13
verses.text: And faith is a good substance, the inheritance of our hope.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 3:15
verses.text: And no wonder if he was perishing for hunger, who lacked the divine nourishment, impelled by the want of which he says: "I will arise and go to my father, and will say unto him: Father, I have sinned against heaven, and before thee".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 3:16
verses.text: Do you not see it plainly declared to us, that we are urged to prayer for the sake of gaining the sacrament? and do you wish to take away that for the sake of which penance is undertaken? Deprive the pilot of the hope of reaching port, and he will wander uncertainly here and there on the waves.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 3:17
verses.text: Take away the crown from the athlete, and he will fail and lie on the course.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 3:18
verses.text: Take from the fisher the power of catching his booty, and he will cease to cast the nets.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 3:19
verses.text: How, then, can he, who suffers hunger in his soul, pray more earnestly to God, if he has no hope of the heavenly food?  17.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 3:20
verses.text: "I have sinned," he says, "against heaven, and before thee".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 3:21
verses.text: He confesses what is clearly a sin unto death, that you may not think that any one doing penance is rightly shut out from pardon.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 3:22
verses.text: For he who has sinned against heaven has sinned either against the kingdom of heaven, or against his own soul, which is a sin unto death, and against God, to Whom alone is said: "Against Thee only have I sinned, and done evil before Thee".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 3:24
verses.text: So quickly does he gain forgiveness, that, as he is coming, and is still a great way off, his father meets him, gives him a kiss, which is the sign of sacred peace; orders the robe to be brought forth, which is the marriage garment, which if any one have not, he is shut out from the marriage feast; places the ring on his hand, which is the pledge of faith and the seal of the Holy Spirit; orders the shoes to be brought out, for he who is about to celebrate the Lord's Passover, about to feast on the Lamb, ought to have his feet protected against all attacks of spiritual wild beasts and the bite of the serpent; bids the calf to be slain, for "Christ our Passover hath been sacrificed".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 3:25
verses.text: For as often as we receive the Blood of the Lord, we proclaim the death of the Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 3:26
verses.text: As, then, He was once slain for all, so whensoever forgiveness of sins is granted, we receive the Sacrament of His Body, that through His Blood there may be remission of sins.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 3:28
verses.text: Therefore most evidently are we bidden by the teaching of the Lord to confer again the grace of the heavenly sacrament on those guilty even of the greatest sins, if they with open confession bear the penance due to their sin.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:1
verses.text: Chapter IV.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:2
verses.text: St.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:3
verses.text: Ambrose turns against the Novatians themselves another objection concerning blasphemy against the Holy Spirit, showing that it consists in an erroneous belief, proving this by St.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:4
verses.text: Peter's words against Simon Magus, and other passages, exhorting the Novatians to return to the Church, affirming that such is our Lord's mercy that even Judas would have found forgiveness had he repented.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:6
verses.text: But we have heard that you are accustomed to bring forward as an objection that which is written: "Every sin and blasphemy shall be forgiven unto men, but blasphemies against the Spirit shall not be forgiven unto men.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:7
verses.text: And whosoever shall speak a word against the Son of Man, it shall be forgiven him, but whosoever shall speak against the Holy Spirit, it shall not be forgiven him, neither in this world, nor in that which is to come".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:8
verses.text: By which quotation the whole of your assertion is destroyed and done away, for it is written: "Every sin and blasphemy shall be forgiven unto men".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:9
verses.text: Why, then, do you not remit them? Why do you bind chains which you do not loose? Why do you tie knots which you do not unfasten? Forgive the others, and deal with those who you think are bound for ever by the authority of the Gospel for sinning against the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:11
verses.text: But let us consider the case of those whom the Lord so binds, going back to the words before the passage quoted, that we may understand it more clearly: The Jews were saying: "This man doth not cast out devils, but by Beelzebub, prince of the devils".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:12
verses.text: Jesus replied: "Every kingdom divided against itself shall be destroyed, and every city or house divided against itself shall not stand; for if Satan casteth out Satan, he is divided against himself, how then shall his kingdom stand? But if I cast out devils by Beelzebub, by whom do your sons cast them out?"  22.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:13
verses.text: Now we see plainly here that the words are expressly used of those who were saying that the Lord Jesus cast out devils through Beelzebub, to whom the Lord gave that answer, because they were of the heritage of Satan, who compared the Saviour of all to Satan, and attributed the grace of Christ to the kingdom of the devil.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:14
verses.text: And that we might know that He was speaking of this blasphemy, He added: "O generation of vipers, how can ye speak good, being yourselves evil?" He says, then, that those who thus speak attain not to forgiveness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:16
verses.text: Then, when Simon, depraved by long practice of magic, had thought he could gain by money the power of conferring the grace of Christ and the infusion of the Holy Spirit, Peter said: "Thou hast neither part nor lot in this faith, for thy heart is not right with God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:17
verses.text: Repent therefore of this thy wickedness, and pray the Lord, if perchance this thought of thy heart may be forgiven thee, for I see that thou art in the bond of iniquity and in the bitterness of gall".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:18
verses.text: We see that Peter by his apostolic authority condemns him who blasphemes against the Holy Spirit through magic vanity, and all the more because he had not the clear consciousness of faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:19
verses.text: And yet he did not exclude him from the hope of forgiveness, for he called him to repentance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:21
verses.text: The Lord then replies to the blasphemy of the Pharisees, and refuses to them the grace of His power, which consists in the remission of sins, because they asserted that His heavenly power rested on the help of the devil.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:22
verses.text: And He affirms that they act with satanic spirit who divide the Church of God, so that He includes the heretics and schismatics of all times, to whom He denies forgiveness, for every other sin is concerned with single persons, this is a sin against all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:23
verses.text: For they alone wish to destroy the grace of Christ who rend asunder the members of the Church for which the Lord Jesus suffered, and the Holy Spirit was given us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:25
verses.text: Lastly, that we may know that He is speaking of those who destroy the unity of the Church, we find it written: "He that is not with Me is against Me, and he that gathered not with Me, scattereth".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:26
verses.text: And that we might know that He is speaking of these, He at once added: "Therefore I say unto you, every sin and blasphemy shall be forgiven unto men, but blasphemies against the Spirit shall not be forgiven unto men".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:27
verses.text: When He says, "Therefore say I unto you," is it not evident that He intended the words following to be laid to heart by us beyond the others? And He rightly added: "A good tree bringeth forth good fruits, but a bad tree bringeth forth bad fruits," for an evil association cannot produce good fruits.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:28
verses.text: The tree, then, is the association; the fruits of the good tree are the children of the Church.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:30
verses.text: Return, then, to the Church, those of you who have wickedly separated yourselves.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:31
verses.text: For He promises forgiveness to all who are converted, since it is written: "Whosoever shall call on the Name of the Lord shall be saved".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:32
verses.text: And lastly, the Jewish people who said of the Lord Jesus, "He hath a devil," and "He casteth out devils through Beelzebub," and who crucified the Lord Jesus, are, by the preaching of Peter, called to baptism, that they may put away the guilt of so great a wickedness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:34
verses.text: But what wonder is it if you should deny salvation to others, who reject your own, though they lose nothing who seek for penance from you? For I suppose that even Judas might through the exceeding mercy of God not have been shut out from forgiveness, if he had expressed his sorrow not before the Jews but before Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:35
verses.text: "I have sinned," he said, "in that I have betrayed righteous blood".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:36
verses.text: Their answer was: "What is that to us, see thou to that".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:37
verses.text: What other reply do you give, when one guilty of a smaller sin confesses his deed to you? What do you answer but this: "What is that to us, see thou to that"? The halter  followed on those words, but the punishment is all the more severe, the smaller the sin is.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:39
verses.text: But if they be not converted, do you at least repent, who by many a slip have fallen from the lofty pinnacle of innocence and faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 4:40
verses.text: We have a good Lord, Whose will it is to forgive all, Who called you by the prophet, and said: "I, even I, am He that blotteth out transgressions, and I will not remember, but do thou remember, and let us plead together".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:1
verses.text: Chapter V.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:2
verses.text: As to the words of St.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:3
verses.text: Peter to Simon Magus, from which the Novatians infer that there was no forgiveness for the latter, it is pointed out that St.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:4
verses.text: Peter, knowing his evil heart, might well use words of doubt, and then by some Old Testament instances it is pointed out that "perchance" does not exclude forgiveness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:5
verses.text: The apostles transmitted to us that penitence, the fruits of which are shown in the case of David.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:6
verses.text: St.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:7
verses.text: Ambrose then adduces the example of the Ephraimites, whose penitence must be followed in order to gain the divine mercy and the sacraments.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:9
verses.text: The Novatians bring up a question from the words of the Apostle Peter.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:10
verses.text: Because he said, "if perchance," they think that he did not imply that forgiveness would be granted on repentance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:11
verses.text: But let them consider concerning whom the words were spoken: of Simon, who did not believe through faith, but was meditating trickery.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:12
verses.text: So too the Lord to him who said, "Lord, I will follow Thee withersoever Thou goest," replied, "Foxes have holes".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:13
verses.text: For He knew that the man's sincerity was not wholly perfect.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:14
verses.text: If, then, the Lord refused to him who was not baptized permission to follow Him, because He saw that he was not sincere, do you wonder that the Apostle did not absolve him who after baptism was guilty of deceit, and whom he declared to be still in the bond of iniquity?  30.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:15
verses.text: But let this be my answer to them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:16
verses.text: As to myself, I say that Peter did not doubt, and I do not think that so great a question can be burked by the questionable interpretation of a single word.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:17
verses.text: For if they think that Peter doubted, did God doubt, Who said to the prophet Jeremiah: "Stand in the court of the Lord's house, and thou shalt give an answer to all Judah, to those who come to worship in the Lord's house, even all the words which I have appointed for thee to answer them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:18
verses.text: Keep not back a word, perchance they will hearken and be converted".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:19
verses.text: Let them say, then, that God also knew not what would happen.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:21
verses.text: But ignorance is not implied in that word, but the common custom of holy Scripture is observed, in order to simplicity of utterance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:22
verses.text: Inasmuch as the Lord says also to Ezekiel: "Son of man, I will send thee unto the house of Israel, to those who have angered Me, both themselves and their fathers, unto this day, and thou shalt say unto them, Thus saith the Lord, if perchance they will hear and be afraid".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:23
verses.text: Did He not know that they could or could not be converted? So, then, that expression is not always a proof of doubt.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:25
verses.text: Lastly, the wise men of this world, who stake all their reputation on expressions and words, do not everywhere use the Latin word forte, "perchance," or its Greek equivalent Ï„á½±Ï‡Î±, as an expression of doubt.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:26
