verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:27
verses.text: But he had no doubt that when all were Joining in the attack one might well be laid low by all.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:29
verses.text: But let us use our own instances rather than foreign ones.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:30
verses.text: You find in the Gospel that the Son Himself says of the Father (when He had sent His servants to His vineyard, and they had been slain), that the Father said, "I will send My well-beloved Son, perchance they will reverence Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:31
verses.text: And in another place the Son says of Himself: "Ye know neither Me nor My Father; for if ye knew Me, ye would perchance know My Father also".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:33
verses.text: If, then, Peter used those words which were used by God without any prejudice to His knowledge, why should we not assume that Peter also used them without prejudice to his belief? For he could not doubt concerning the gift of Christ, Who had given him the power of forgiving sins; especially  since he was bound not to leave any place for the craftiness of heretics who desire to deprive men of hope, in order the more easily to insinuate into the despairing their opinion as to the reiteration of baptism.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:35
verses.text: But the apostles, having this baptism according to the direction of Christ, taught repentance, promised forgiveness, and remitted guilt, as David taught when he said: "Blessed are they whose transgressions are forgiven, and whose sins are covered.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:36
verses.text: Blessed is the man to whom the Lord hath not imputed sin".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:37
verses.text: He calls each blessed, both him whose sins are remitted by the font, and him whose sin is covered by good works.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:38
verses.text: For he who repents ought not only to wash away his sin by his tears, but also to cover and hide his former transgressions by amended deeds, that sin may not be imputed to him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:40
verses.text: Let us, then, cover our falls by our subsequent acts; let us purify ourselves by tears, that the Lord our God may hear us when we lament, as He heard Ephraim when weeping, as it is written: "I have surely heard Ephraim weeping".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:41
verses.text: And He expressly repeats the very words of Ephraim: "Thou hast chastised me and I was chastised, like a calf I was not trained".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:42
verses.text: For a calf disports itself, and leaves its stall, and so Ephraim was untrained like a calf far away from the stall; because he had forsaken the stall of the Lord, followed Jeroboam, and worshipped the calves, which future event was prophetically indicated through Aaron, namely, that the people of the Jews would fall after this manner.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:43
verses.text: And so repenting, Ephraim says: "Turn Thou me, and I shall be turned, for Thou art the Lord my God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:44
verses.text: Surely in the end of my captivity I repented, and after I learned I mourned over the days of confusion, and subjected myself to Thee because I received reproach and made Thee known".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:46
verses.text: We see how to repent, with what words and with what acts, that the days of sin are called "days of confusion;" for there is confusion when Christ is denied.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:48
verses.text: Let us, then, submit ourselves to God, and not be subject to sin, and when we ponder the remembrance of our offences, let us blush as though at some disgrace, and not speak of them as a glory to us, as some boast of overcoming modesty, or putting down the feeling of justice.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:49
verses.text: Let our conversion be such, that we who did not know God may now ourselves declare Him to others, that the Lord, moved by such a conversion on our part, may answer to us: "Ephraim is from youth a dear son, a pleasant child, for since My words are concerning him, I will verily remember him, therefore have I hastened to be over him; I will surely have mercy on him, saith the Lord".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:51
verses.text: And what mercy He promises us, the Lord also shows, when He says further on: "I have satiated every thirsty soul, and have satisfied every hungry soul.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:52
verses.text: Therefore, I awaked and beheld, and My sleep was sweet unto Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:53
verses.text: We observe that the Lord promises His sacraments to those who sin.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 5:54
verses.text: Let us, then, all be converted to the Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:1
verses.text: Chapter VI.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:2
verses.text: St.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:3
verses.text: Ambrose teaches out of the prophet Isaiah what they must do who have fallen.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:4
verses.text: Then referring to our Lord's proverbial expression respecting piping and dancing, he condemns dances.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:5
verses.text: Next by the example of Jeremiah he sets forth the necessary accompaniments of repentance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:6
verses.text: And lastly, in order to show the efficacy of this medicine of penance, he enumerates the names of many who have used it for themselves or for others.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:8
verses.text: But if they be not converted, do you at least repent, who by many a slip have fallen from the lofty pinnacle of innocence and faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:9
verses.text: We have a good Lord, Whose will it is to forgive all, Who called you by the prophet and said: "I, even I, am He that blotteth out thy transgressions, and I will not remember, but do thou remember that we may plead together".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:10
verses.text: "I," He says, "will not remember, but do thou remember," that is to say, "I do not recall those transgressions which I have forgiven thee, which are covered, as it were, with oblivion, but do thou remember them.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:11
verses.text: I will not remember them because of My grace, do thou remember them in order to correction; remember, thou mayest know that the sin is forgiven, boast not as though innocent, that thou aggravate not the sin, but thou wilt be justified, confess thy sin".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:12
verses.text: For a shamefaced confession of sins looses the bands of transgression.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:14
verses.text: You see what God requires of you, that you remember that grace which you have received, and boast not as though you had not received it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:15
verses.text: You see by how complete a promise of remission He draws you to confession.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:16
verses.text: Take heed, lest by resisting the commandments of God you fall into the  offence of the Jews, to whom the Lord Jesus said: "We piped to you and ye danced not; we wailed and ye wept not".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:18
verses.text: The words are ordinary words, but the mystery is not ordinary.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:19
verses.text: And so one must be on one's guard, lest, deceived by any common interpretation of this saying, one should suppose that the movements of wanton dances and the madness of the stage were commended; for these are full of evil in youthful age.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:20
verses.text: But the dancing is commended which David practised before the ark of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:21
verses.text: For everything is seemly which is done for religion, so that we need be ashamed of no service which tends to the worship and honouring of Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:23
verses.text: Dancing, then, which is an accompaniment of pleasures and luxury, is not spoken of, but spiritually such as that wherewith one raises the eager body, and suffers not the limbs to lie slothfully on the ground, nor to grow stiff in their accustomed tracks.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:24
verses.text: Paul danced spiritually, when for us he stretched forward, and forgetting the things which were behind, and aiming at those which were before, he pressed on to the prize of Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:25
verses.text: And you, too, when you come to baptism, are warned to raise the hands, and to cause your feet wherewith you ascend to things eternal to be swifter.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:26
verses.text: This dancing accompanies faith, and is the companion of grace.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:28
verses.text: This, then, is the mystery.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:29
verses.text: "We piped to you," singing in truth the song of the New Testament, "and ye danced not".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:30
verses.text: That is, did not raise your souls to the spiritual grace.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:31
verses.text: "We wailed, and ye wept not".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:32
verses.text: That is, ye did not repent.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:33
verses.text: And therefore was the Jewish people forsaken, because it did not repent, and rejected grace.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:34
verses.text: Repentance came by John, grace by Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:35
verses.text: He, as the Lord, gives the one; the other is proclaimed, as it were, by the servant.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:36
verses.text: The Church, then, keeps both that it may both attain to grace and not cast away repentance, for grace is the gift of One Who confers it; repentance is the remedy of the sinner.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:38
verses.text: Jeremiah knew that penitence was a great remedy, which he in his Lamentations took up for Jerusalem, and brings forward Jerusalem itself as repenting, when he says: "She wept sore in the night, and her tears are on her cheeks, nor is there one to comfort her of all who love her.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:39
verses.text: The ways of Sion do mourn".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:40
verses.text: And he says further: "For these things I weep, my eyes have grown dim with weeping, because he who used to comfort me is gone far from me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:41
verses.text: We notice that he thought this the bitterest addition to his woes, that he who used to comfort the mourner was gone far from him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:42
verses.text: How, then, can you take away the very comfort by refusing to repentance the hope of forgiveness?  46.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:43
verses.text: But let those who repent learn how they ought to carry it out, with what zeal, with what affection, with what intention of mind, with what shaking of the inmost bowels, with what conversion of heart: "Behold," he says, "O Lord, that I am in distress, my bowels are troubled by my weeping, my heart is turned within me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:45
verses.text: Here you recognize the intention of the soul, the faithfulness of the mind, the disposition of the body: "The elders of the daughters of Sion sat," he says, "upon the ground, they put dust upon their heads, they girded themselves with haircloth, the princes hung their heads to the ground, the virgins of Jerusalem fainted with weeping, my eyes grew dim, my bowels were troubled, my glory was poured on the earth".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:47
verses.text: So, too, did the people of Nineveh mourn, and escaped the destruction of their city.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:48
verses.text: Such is the remedial power of repentance, that God seems because of it to change His intention.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:49
verses.text: To escape is, then, in your own power; the Lord wills to be entreated, He wills that men should hope in Him, He wills that supplication should be made to Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:50
verses.text: Thou art a man, and willest to be asked to forgive, and dost thou think that God will pardon thee without asking Him?  49.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:51
verses.text: The Lord Himself wept over Jerusalem, that, inasmuch as it would not weep itself, it might obtain forgiveness through the tears of the Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:52
verses.text: He wills that we should weep in order that we may escape, as you find it in the Gospel: "Daughters of Jerusalem, weep not for Me, but weep for yourselves".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:54
verses.text: David wept, and obtained of the divine mercy the removal of the death of the people who were perishing, when of the three things proposed for his choice he selected that in which he might have the most experience of the divine mercy.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:55
verses.text: Why do you blush to weep for your sins, when God commanded even the prophets to weep for the people?  51.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:56
verses.text: And, lastly, Ezekiel was bidden to weep for Jerusalem, and he took the book,  at the beginning of which was written: "Lamentation, and melody, and woe," two things sad and one pleasant, for he shall be saved in the future who has wept most in this age.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:57
verses.text: "For the heart of the wise is in the house of mourning, and the heart of fools in the house of feasting".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 6:58
verses.text: And the Lord Himself said: "Blessed are ye that weep now, for ye shall laugh".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:1
verses.text: Chapter VII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:2
verses.text: An exhortation to mourning and confession of sins for Christ is moved by these and the tears of the Church.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:3
verses.text: Illustration from the story of Lazarus.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:4
verses.text: After showing that the Novatians are the successors of those who planned to kill Lazarus, St.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:5
verses.text: Ambrose argues that the full forgiveness of every sin is signified by the odour of the ointment poured by Mary on the feet of Christ; and further, that the Novatian heretics find their likeness in Judas, who grudged and envied when others rejoiced.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:7
verses.text: Let us, then, mourn for a time, that we may rejoice for eternity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:8
verses.text: Let us fear the Lord, let us anticipate Him with the confession of our sins, let us correct our backslidings and amend our faults, lest of us too it be said: "Woe is me, my soul, for the godly man is perished from the earth, and there is none amongst men to correct them".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:10
verses.text: Why do you fear to confess your sins to our good Lord? "Set them forth," He says, "that thou mayest be justified".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:11
verses.text: The rewards of justification are set before him who is still guilty of sin, for he is justified who voluntarily confesses his own sin; and lastly, "the just man is his own accuser in the beginning of his speaking".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:12
verses.text: The Lord knows all things, but He waits for your words, not that He may punish, but that He may pardon.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:13
verses.text: It is not His will that the devil should triumph over you and accuse you when you conceal your sins.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:14
verses.text: Be beforehand with your accuser: if you accuse yourself, you will fear no accuser; if you report yourself, though you were dead you shall live.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:16
verses.text: Christ will come to your grave, and if He finds there weeping for you Martha the woman of good service, and Mary who carefully heard the Word of God, like holy Church which has chosen the best part, He will be moved with compassion, when at your death He shall see the tears of many and will say: "Where have ye laid him?" that is to say, in what condition of guilt is he? in which rank of penitents? I would see him for whom ye weep, that he himself may move Me with his tears.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:17
verses.text: I will see if he is already dead to that sin for which forgiveness is entreated.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:19
verses.text: The people will say to Him, "Come and see".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:20
verses.text: What is the meaning of "Come"? It means, Let forgiveness of sins come, let the life of the departed come, the resurrection of the dead, let Thy kingdom come to this sinner also.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:22
verses.text: He will come and will command that the stone be taken away which his fall has laid on the shoulders of the sinner.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:23
verses.text: He could have removed the stone by a word of command, for even inanimate nature is wont to obey the bidding of Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:24
verses.text: He could by the silent power of His working have removed the stone of the sepulchre, at Whose Passion the stones being suddenly removed many sepulchres of the dead were opened, but He bade men remove the stone, in very truth indeed, that the unbelieving might believe what they saw, and see the dead rising again, but in a type that He might give us the power of lightening the burden of sins, the heavy pressure as it were upon the guilty.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:25
verses.text: Ours it is to remove the burdens, His to raise again, His to bring forth from the tombs those set free from their bands.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:27
verses.text: So the Lord Jesus, seeing the heavy burden of the sinner, weeps, for the Church alone He suffers not to weep.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:28
verses.text: He has compassion with His beloved, and says to him that is dead, "Come forth," that is, Thou who liest in darkness of conscience, and in the squalor of thy sins, as in the prison-house of the guilty, come forth, declare thy sins that thou mayest be justified.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:29
verses.text: "For with the mouth confession is made unto salvation".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:31
verses.text: If you have confessed at the call of Christ the bars will be broken, and every chain loosed, even the stench of the bodily corruption be grievous.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:32
verses.text: For he had been dead four days and his flesh stank in the tomb; but He Whose flesh saw no corruption was three days in the sepulchre, for He knew no evils of the flesh, which consists of the substances of the four elements.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:33
verses.text: However great, then, the stench of the dead body may be, it is all done away so soon as the sacred ointment has shed its odour; and the dead rises again, and the command is given to loose his hands who till now was in sin; the covering is taken from his face which veiled the truth of the grace which he had received.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:34
verses.text: But since he has received forgiveness, the command is given to uncover his face, to lay bare his features.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:35
verses.text: For he whose sin is forgiven has nothing whereof to be ashamed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:37
verses.text: But in the presence of such grace given by the Lord, of such a miracle of divine bounty, when all ought to have rejoiced, the wicked were stirred up and gathered a council against Christ, and wished moreover to kill Lazarus also.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:38
verses.text: Do you not recognize that you are the successors of those whose hardness you inherit? For you too are angry and gather a council against the Church, because you see the dead come to life again in the Church, and to be raised again by receiving forgiveness of their sins.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:39
verses.text: And thus, so far as in you, you desire to slay again through envy those who are raised to life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:41
verses.text: But Jesus does not revoke His benefits, nay, rather He amplifies them by additions of His liberality, He anxiously revisits him who was raised again, and rejoicing in the gift of the restored life, He comes to the feast which His Church has prepared for Him, at which he who had been dead is found as one amongst those sitting down with Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:43
verses.text: Then all wonder who look upon him with the pure gaze of the mind, who are free from envy, for such children the Church has.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:44
verses.text: They wonder, as I said, how he who yesterday and the day before lay in the tomb is one of those sitting with the Lord Jesus.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:46
verses.text: Mary herself pours ointment on the feet of the Lord Jesus.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:47
verses.text: Perchance for this reason on His feet, because one of the lowliest has been snatched from death, for we are all the body of Christ, but others perchance are the more honourable members.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:48
verses.text: The Apostle was the mouth of Christ, for he said, "Ye seek a proof of Christ that speaketh in me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:49
verses.text: The prophets through whom He spake of things to come were His mouth, would that I might be found worthy to be His foot, and may Mary pour on me her precious ointment, and anoint me and wipe away my sin.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:51
verses.text: What, then, we read concerning Lazarus we ought to believe of every sinner who is converted, who, though he may have been stinking, nevertheless is cleansed by the precious ointment of faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:52
verses.text: For faith has such grace that there where the dead stank the day before, now the whole house is filled with good odour.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:54
verses.text: The house of Corinth stank, when it was written concerning it: "It is reported that there is fornication among you, and such fornication as is not even among the Gentiles".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:55
verses.text: There was a stench, for a little leaven had corrupted the whole lump.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:56
verses.text: A good odour began when it was said: "If ye forgive anything to any one I forgive also.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:57
verses.text: For what I also have forgiven, for your sakes have I done it in the person of Christ".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:58
verses.text: And so, the sinner being set free, there was great joy in that place, and the whole house was filled with the odour of the sweetness of grace.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:59
verses.text: Wherefore the Apostle, knowing well that he had shed upon all the ointment of apostolic forgiveness, says: "We are a sweet savour of Christ unto God in them that are saved".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:61
verses.text: At the pouring forth, then, of this ointment all rejoice; Judas alone speaks against it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:62
verses.text: So, too, now he who is a sinner speaks against it, he who is a traitor blames it, but he is himself blamed by Christ, as he knows not the remedy of the Lord's death, and understands not the mystery of that so great burial.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:63
verses.text: For the Lord both suffered and died that He might redeem us from death.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:64
verses.text: This is manifest from the most excellent value from His death, which is sufficient for the absolution of the sinner, and his restoration to fresh grace; so that all may come and wonder at his sitting at table with Christ, and may praise God, saying: "Let us eat and feast, for he was dead and is alive again, had perished and is found".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 7:65
verses.text: But any one devoid of faith objects: "Why does He eat with publicans and sinners?" This is his answer: "They that are whole have no need of the physician, but they that are sick".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:1
verses.text: Chapter VIII.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:2
verses.text: In urging repentance St.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:3
verses.text: Ambrose turns to his own case, expressing the wish that he could wash our Lord's feet like the woman in the Gospel, which is a great pattern of penitence, though such as cannot attain to it find acceptance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:4
verses.text: He prays for himself, especially that he may sorrow with sinners, who are better than himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:5
verses.text: Those for whom Christ died are not to be contemned.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:7
verses.text: Show, then, your wound to the Physician that He may heal it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:8
verses.text: Though you show it not, He knows it, but waits to hear your voice.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:9
verses.text: Do away your scars by tears.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:10
verses.text: Thus did that woman in the Gospel, and wiped out the stench of her sin; thus did she  wash away her fault, when washing the feet of Jesus with her tears.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:12
verses.text: Would that Thou, Lord Jesus, mightest reserve for me the washing off from Thy feet of the stains contracted since Thou walkest in me! O that Thou mightest offer to me to cleanse the pollution which I by my deeds have caused on Thy steps! But whence can I obtain living water, wherewith I may wash Thy feet? If I have no water I have tears, and whilst with them I wash Thy feet I trust to cleanse myself.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:13
verses.text: Whence is it that Thou shouldst say to me: "His sins which are many are forgiven, because he loved much"? I confess that I owe more, and that more has been forgiven me who have been called to the priesthood from the tumult and strife of the law courts and the dread of public administration; and therefore I fear that I may be found ungrateful, if I, to whom more has been forgiven, love less.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:15
verses.text: But all are not able to equal that woman, who was deservedly preferred even to Simon, who was giving the feast to the Lord; who gave a lesson to all who desire to gain forgiveness, by kissing the feet of Christ, washing them with her tears, wiping them with her hair, and anointing them with ointment.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:17
verses.text: In a kiss is the sign of love, and therefore the Lord Jesus says: "Let her kiss Me with the kisses of her mouth".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:18
verses.text: What is the meaning of the hair, but that you may learn that, having laid aside all the pomp of worldly trappings, you must implore pardon, throw yourself on the earth with tears, and prostrate on the ground move pity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:19
verses.text: In the ointment, too, is set forth the savour of a good conversation.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:20
verses.text: David was a king, yet he said: "Every night will I wash my bed, I will water my couch with tears".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:21
verses.text: And therefore he obtained such a favour, as that of his house the Virgin should be chosen, who by her child-bearing should bring forth Christ for us.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:22
verses.text: Therefore is this woman also praised in the Gospel.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:24
verses.text: Nevertheless if we are unable to equal her, the Lord Jesus knows also how to aid the weak, when there is no one who can prepare the feast, or bring the ointment, or carry with her a spring of living water.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:25
verses.text: He comes Himself to the sepulchre.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:27
verses.text: Would that Thou wouldst vouchsafe to come to this sepulchre of mine, O Lord Jesus, that Thou wouldst wash me with Thy tears, since in my hardened eyes I possess not such tears as to be able to wash away my offence.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:28
verses.text: If Thou shalt weep for me I shall be saved; if I am worthy of Thy tears I shall cleanse the stench of all my offences; if I am worthy that Thou weep but a little, Thou wilt call me out of the tomb of this body and will say: "Come forth," that my meditations may not be kept pent up in the narrow limits of this body, but may go forth to Christ, and move in the light, that I may think no more on works of darkness but on works of light.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:29
verses.text: For he who thinks on sins endeavours to shut himself up within his own consciousness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:31
verses.text: Call forth, then, Thy servant.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:32
verses.text: Although bound with the chain of my sins I have my feet fastened and my hands tied; being now buried in dead thoughts and works, yet at Thy call I shall go forth free, and shall be found one of those sitting at Thy feast, and Thy house shall be filled with precious ointment.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:33
verses.text: If Thou hast vouchsafed to redeem any one, Thou wilt preserve him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:34
verses.text: For it shall be said, "See, he was not brought up in the bosom of the Church, nor trained from childhood, but hurried from the judgment-seat, brought away from the vanities of this world, growing accustomed to the singing of the choir instead of the shout of the crier, but he continues in the priesthood not by his own strength, but by the grace of Christ, and sits among the guests at the heavenly table.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:36
verses.text: Preserve, O Lord, Thy work, guard the gift which Thou hast given even to him who shrank from it.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:37
verses.text: For I knew that I was not worthy to be called a bishop, because I had devoted myself to this world, but by Thy grace I am what I am.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:38
verses.text: And I am indeed the least of all bishops, and the lowest in merit; yet since I too have undertaken some labour for Thy holy Church, watch over this fruit, and let not him whom when lost Thou didst call to the priesthood, to be lost when a priest.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:39
verses.text: And first grant that I may know how with inmost affection to mourn with those who sin; for this is a very great virtue, since it is written: "And thou shalt not rejoice over the children of Judah in the day of their destruction, and speak not proudly in the day of their trouble".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:40
verses.text: Grant that so often as the sin of any one who has fallen is made known to me I may suffer with him, and not chide him proudly, but mourn and weep, so that weeping over another I may mourn for myself, saying, "Tamar hath been more righteous than I".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:42
verses.text: Perchance a maiden may have fallen, deceived and hurried away by those occasions which are the sources of sins.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:43
verses.text: Well, we who are older sin, too.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:44
verses.text: In us, too, the law of this flesh wars against the law of our mind, and makes us captives of sin, so that we do what we would not.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:45
verses.text: Her youth is an excuse for her, I now have none, for she ought to learn, we ought to teach.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:46
verses.text: So that "Tamar hath been more righteous than I".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:48
verses.text: We inveigh against some one's covetousness, let us call to mind whether we ourselves have never done anything covetously; and if we have, since covetousness is the root of all evils, and is working in our bodies like a serpent secretly under the earth, let each of us say: "Tamar hath been more righteous than I".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:50
verses.text: If we have been seriously moved against any one, a layman may act hastily for a smaller matter than a bishop.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:51
verses.text: Let us ponder that with ourselves and say, He who is reproved for quick temper is more righteous than I.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:52
verses.text: For if we thus speak, we guard ourselves against this, that the Lord Jesus or one of His disciples should say to us: "Thou beholdest the mote in thy brother's eye, but beholdest not the beam which is in thine own eye.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:53
verses.text: Thou hypocrite, cast out first the beam out of thine own eye, and then shalt thou see to cast out the mote out of thy brother's eye".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:55
verses.text: Let us, then, not be ashamed to say that our fault is more serious than that of him whom we think we must reprove, for this is what Judah did who reprimanded Tamar, and remembering his own fault said: "Tamar is more righteous than I".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:56
verses.text: In which saying there is a deep mystery and a moral precept; and therefore is his offence not reckoned to him, because he accused himself before he was accused by others.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:58
verses.text: Let us, then, not rejoice over the sin of any one, but rather let us mourn, for it is written: "Rejoice not against me, O my enemy, because I have fallen, for I shall arise; for if I sit in darkness the Lord shall be a light unto me, I will bear the indignation of the Lord, because I have sinned against Him, until He maintain my cause, and execute judgment for me, and bring me forth to the light, and I shall behold His righteousness.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:59
verses.text: Mine enemy, too, shall see it and shall be covered with confusion, which said unto me, Where is the Lord thy God? Mine eyes shall behold her, and she shall be for treading down as the mire in the streets".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:60
verses.text: And this not unreservedly, for he who rejoices at the fall of another rejoices at the victory of the devil.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:61
verses.text: Let us, then, rather mourn when we hear that one has perished for whom Christ died, Who despises not even the straw in time of harvest.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 8:63
verses.text: O that He may not cast away this straw at His harvest, the empty stalks of my produce; but may He gather it in, as is said by some one: "Woe is me, for I am become as one that gathereth straw in harvest, and grape gleanings in the vintage," that He may eat of the firstfruits at least of His grace in me, though He approve not the later fruit.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:1
verses.text: Chapter IX.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:2
verses.text: In what way faith is necessary for repentance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:3
verses.text: Means for paying our debts, in which work, prayer, tears, and fasting are of more value than money.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:4
verses.text: Some instances are adduced, and St.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:5
verses.text: Ambrose declares that generosity is profitable, but only when joined with faith; it is, moreover, liable to certain defects.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:6
verses.text: He goes on to speak of some defects in repentance, such as too great haste in seeking reconciliation, considering abstinence from sacraments all that is needed, of committing sin in hope of repenting later.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:8
verses.text: So, then, it is fitting for us to believe both that sinners must repent and that forgiveness is to be given on repentance, yet still as hoping for forgiveness as granted upon faith, not as a debt, for it is one thing to earn, and another presumptuously to claim a right.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:9
verses.text: Faith asks for forgiveness, as it were, by covenant, but presumption is more akin to demand than to request.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:10
verses.text: Pay first that which you owe, that you may be in a position to ask for what you have hoped.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:11
verses.text: Come with the disposition of an honest debtor, that you may not contract a fresh liability, but may pay that which is due of the existing debt with the possessions of your faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:13
verses.text: He who owes a debt to God has more help towards payment than he who is indebted to man.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:14
verses.text: Man requires money for money, and this is not always at the debtor's command.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:15
verses.text: God demands the affection of the heart, which is in our own power.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:16
verses.text: No one who owes a debt to God is poor, except one who has made himself poor.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:17
verses.text: And even if he have nothing to sell, yet has he wherewith to pay.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:18
verses.text: Prayer, fasting, and tears are the resources of an honest debtor, and much more abundant than if one from the price of his estate offered money without faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:20
verses.text: Ananias was poor, when after selling his land he brought the money to the  apostles, and was not able with it to pay his debt, but involved himself the more.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:21
verses.text: That widow was rich who cast her two small pieces into the treasury, of whom Christ said: "This poor widow hath cast in more than they all".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:22
verses.text: For God requires not money but faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:24
verses.text: And I do not deny that sins may be diminished by liberal gifts to the poor, but only if faith commend what is spent.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:25
verses.text: For what would the giving of one's whole property benefit without charity?  84.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:26
verses.text: There are some who aim at the credit of generosity for pride alone, because they wish thereby to gain the good opinion of the multitude for leaving nothing to themselves; but whilst they are seeking rewards in this life, they are laying up none for the life to come, and having received their reward here they cannot hope for it there.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:28
verses.text: Some again, having, through impulsive excitement and not after long consideration, given their possessions to the Church, think that they can claim them back.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:29
verses.text: These gain neither the first nor the second reward, for the gift was made thoughtlessly, its recall sacrilegiously.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:31
verses.text: Some repent of having distributed their property to the poor.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:32
verses.text: But they who are doing penance must not repent of this, lest they repent of their own repentance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:33
verses.text: For many seek for penance through fear of future punishment, being conscious of their sins, and having received their penance are held back by fear of the public entreaties.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:34
verses.text: These persons seem to have sought for repentance for their evil deeds, but to exercise it for their good ones.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:36
verses.text: Some seek penance because they wish to be at once restored to communion.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:37
verses.text: These wish not so much to loose themselves as to bind the priest, for they do not put off the guilt from their own conscience, but lay it on that of the priest, to whom the command is given: "Give not that which is holy to the dogs, neither cast your pearls before the swine;" that is to say, that partaking of the holy Communion is not to be allowed to those polluted with impurity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:39
verses.text: And so one may see those walking in other attire, who ought to be weeping and groaning because they had defiled the robe of sanctification and grace; and women loading their ears with pearls, and weighing down their necks, who had better have bent to Christ than to gold, and who ought to be weeping for themselves, because they have lost the pearl from heaven.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:41
verses.text: There are, again, some who think that it is penitence to abstain from the heavenly sacraments.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:42
verses.text: These are too cruel judges of themselves, who prescribe a penalty for themselves but refuse the remedy, who ought to be mourning over their self-imposed penalty, because it deprives them of heavenly grace.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:44
verses.text: Others think that licence is granted them to sin, because the hope of penitence is before them, whereas penitence is the remedy, not an incentive to sin.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:45
verses.text: For the salve is necessary for the wound, not the wound for the salve, since a salve is sought because of the wound, the wound is not wished for on account of the salve.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 9:46
verses.text: The hope which is put off to a future season is but feeble, for every season is uncertain, and hope does not outlive all time.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 10:1
verses.text: Chapter X.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 10:2
verses.text: In order to do away with the feeling of shame which holds back the guilty from public penance, St.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 10:3
verses.text: Ambrose points out the advantage of prayers offered by the whole Church, and sets forth the example of saints who have sorrowed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 10:4
verses.text: Then, after reproving those who imagine that penance may be often repeated, he points out the difficulty of repentance, and how it is to be carried out.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 10:6
verses.text: Can any one endure that you should blush to entreat God, when you do not blush to entreat a man? That you should be ashamed to entreat Him Who knows you fully, when you are not ashamed to confess your sins to a man who knows you not? Do you shrink from witnesses and sympathizers in your prayers, when, if you have to satisfy a man, you must visit many and entreat them to be kind enough to intervene; when you throw yourself at a man's knees, kiss his feet, bring your children, still unconscious of guilt, to entreat also for their father's pardon? And you disdain to do this in the Church in order to entreat God, in order to gain for yourself the support of the holy congregation; where there is no cause for shame, except indeed not to confess, since we are all sinners, amongst whom he is the most praiseworthy who is the most humble; he is the most just who feels himself the lowest.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 10:8
verses.text: Let the Church, our Mother, weep for  you, and wash away your guilt with her tears; let Christ see you mourning and say, "Blessed are ye that are sad, for ye shall rejoice".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 10:9
verses.text: It pleases Him that many should entreat for one.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 10:10
verses.text: In the Gospel, too, moved by the widow's tears, because many were weeping for her, He raised her son.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 10:11
verses.text: He heard Peter more quickly when He raised Dorcas, because the poor were mourning over the death of the woman.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 10:12
verses.text: He also forthwith forgave Peter, for he wept most bitterly.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 10:13
verses.text: And if you weep bitterly Christ will look upon you and your guilt shall leave you.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 10:14
verses.text: For the application of pain does away with the enjoyment of the wickedness and the delight of the sin.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 10:15
verses.text: And so while mourning over our past sins we shut the door against fresh ones, and from the condemnation of our guilt there arises as it were a training in innocence.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 10:17
verses.text: Let, then, nothing call you away from penitence, for this you have in common with the saints, and would that such sorrowing for sin as that of the saints were copied by you.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 10:18
verses.text: David, as it were, "ate ashes for bread, and mingled his drink with weeping," and therefore now rejoices the more because he wept the more: "Mine eyes ran down," he said, "with rivers of water".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 10:20
verses.text: John wept sore, and, as he tells us, the mysteries of Christ were revealed to him.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 10:21
verses.text: But that woman who, when she was in sin and ought to have wept, nevertheless rejoiced, and covered herself with a robe of purple and scarlet, and adorned herself with much gold and precious stones, now mourns the misery of eternal weeping.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 10:23
verses.text: Deservedly are they blamed who think that they often do penance, for they are wanton against Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 10:24
verses.text: For if they went through their penance in truth, they would not think that it could be repeated again; for as there is but one baptism, so there is but one course of penance, so far as the outward practice goes, for we must repent of our daily faults, but this latter has to do with lighter faults, the former with such as are graver.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 10:26
verses.text: But I have more easily found such as had preserved their innocence than such as had fittingly repented.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 10:27
verses.text: Does any one think that that is penitence where there still exists the striving after earthly honours, where wine flows, and even conjugal connection takes place? The world must be renounced; less sleep must be indulged in than nature demands; it must be broken by groans, interrupted by sighs, put aside by prayers; the mode of life must be such that we die to the usual habits of life.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 10:28
verses.text: Let the man deny himself and be wholly changed, as in the fable they relate of a certain youth, who left his home because of his love for a harlot, and, having subdued his love, returned; then one day meeting his old favourite and not speaking to her, she, being surprised and supposing that he had not recognized her, said, when they met again, "It is I".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 10:29
verses.text: "But," was his answer, "I am not the former I".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 10:31
verses.text: Well then did the Lord say: "If any man will come after Me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross and follow Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 10:32
verses.text: For they who are dead and buried in Christ ought not again to make their conclusions as though living in the world.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 10:33
verses.text: "Touch not," it is said, "nor attend to those things which tend to corruption by their very use, for the very customs of this life corrupt integrity".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:1
verses.text: Chapter XI.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:2
verses.text: The possibility of repentance is a reason why baptism should not be deferred to old age, a practice which is against the will of God in holy Scripture.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:3
verses.text: But it is of no use to practise penance whilst still serving lusts.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:4
verses.text: These must be first subdued.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:6
verses.text: Good, then, is penitence, and if there were no place for it, every one would defer the grace of cleansing by baptism to old age.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:7
verses.text: And a sufficient reason is that it is better, to have a robe to mend, than none to put on; but as that which has been repaired once is restored, so that which is frequently mended is destroyed.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:9
verses.text: And the Lord has given a sufficient warning to those who put off repentance, when He says: "Repent ye, for the kingdom of heaven is at hand".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:10
verses.text: We know not at what hour the thief will come, we know not whether our soul may be required of us this next night.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:11
verses.text: God cast Adam out of Paradise immediately after his fault; there was no delay.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:12
verses.text: At once the fallen were severed from all their enjoyments that they might do penance; at once God clothed them with garments of skins, not of silk.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:14
verses.text: And what reason is there for putting  off? Is it that you may sin yet more? Then because God is good you are evil, and "despise the riches of His goodness and long-suffering".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:15
verses.text: But the goodness of the Lord ought rather to draw you to repentance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:16
verses.text: Wherefore holy David says to all: "Come, let us worship and fall down before Him, and mourn before our Lord Who made us".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:17
verses.text: But for a sinner who has died without repentance, because nothing remains but to mourn grievously and to weep, you find him groaning and saying: "O my son Absalom! my son Absalom!" For him who is wholly dead mourning is without alleviation.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:19
verses.text: But of those who as exiles and banished from their ancestral homes, which the holy law of Moses had assigned them, will be entangled in the errors of the world, you hear him saying: "By the waters of Babylon we sat down and wept, when we remembered Zion".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:20
verses.text: He sets forth the wailings of those who have fallen, and shows that they who are living in this condition of passing time and changing circumstances ought to repent, after the example of those who, as a reward for sin, had been led into miserable captivity.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:22
verses.text: But nothing causes such exceeding grief as when any one, lying under the captivity of sin, calls to mind whence he has fallen, because he turned aside to carnal and earthly things, instead of directing his mind in the beautiful ways of the knowledge of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:24
verses.text: So you find Adam concealing himself, when he knew that God was present, and wishing to be hidden when called by God with that voice which wounded the soul of him who was hiding: "Adam, where art thou?" That is to say, Wherefore hidest thou thyself? Why art thou concealed? Why dost thou avoid Him, Whom thou once didst long to see? A guilty conscience is so burdensome that it punishes itself without a judge, and wishes for covering, and yet is bare before God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:26
verses.text: And so no one in a state of sin ought to claim a right to or the use of the sacraments, for it is written: "Thou hast sinned, be still".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:27
verses.text: As David says in the Psalm lately quoted: "We hanged our harps upon the willows in the midst thereof;" and again: "How shall we sing the Lord's song in a strange land?" For if the flesh wars against the mind, and is not subject to the guidance of the Spirit, that is a strange land which is not subdued by the toil of the cultivator, and so cannot produce the fruits of charity, patience, and peace.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:28
verses.text: It is better, then, to be still when you cannot practise the works of repentance, lest in the very acts of repentance there be that which afterward will need further repentance.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:29
verses.text: For if it be once entered upon and not rightly carried out, it obtains not the result of a first repentance and takes away the use of a later one.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:31
verses.text: When, then, the flesh resists, the soul must be intent upon God, and if results do not follow, let not faith fail.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:32
verses.text: And if the enticements of the flesh come upon us, or the powers of the enemy attack us, let the soul keep in submission to God.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:33
verses.text: For we are then specially oppressed when the flesh yields.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:34
verses.text: And some there are who trouble heavily the wretched soul, seeking to deprive it of all protection.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:35
verses.text: To which case the words apply: "Rase it, rase it, even to the foundations".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:37
verses.text: And David, pitying her, says: "O wretched daughter of Babylon".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:38
verses.text: Wretched indeed, as being the daughter of Babylon, when she ceased to be the daughter of Jerusalem.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:39
verses.text: And yet he calls for a healer for her, and says: "Blessed is he who shall take thy little ones and dash them against the rock".

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:40
verses.text: That is to say, shall dash all corrupt and filthy thoughts against Christ, Who by His fear and His rebuke will break down all motions against reason, so as, if any one is seized by an adulterous love, to extinguish the fire, that he may by his zeal put away the love of a harlot, and deny himself that he may gain Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:42
verses.text: We have then learned that we must do penance, and this at a time when the heat of luxury and sin is giving way; and that we, when under the dominion of sin, must show ourselves Godfearing by refraining, rather than allowing ourselves in evil practices.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:43
verses.text: For if it is said to Moses when he was desiring to draw nearer: "Put off thy shoes from off thy feet," how much  more must we free the feet of our soul from the bonds of the body, and clear our steps from all connection with this world.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:44
verses.text: Note on the Penitential Discipline of the Early Church.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:45
verses.text: It was always believed in the Church that the power of binding and loosing had been entrusted by our Lord to His apostles, and by them handed on to their successors in the ministry.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:46
verses.text: The earlier practice would seem to have been short and simple: exclusion from Communion, some outward discipline, not always continued for a long period, and reconciliation on true repentance, these matters being decided by the bishop at his discretion.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:47
verses.text: Gradually the practice became more systematized, various periods of discipline were prescribed for various sins, and the time for this discipline was lengthened.

verses.name: Ambrose: On Repentance Book II 11:63
verses.text: As the word penitentia includes not merely sorrow for sin and change of heart, but also penance, or the penalty inflicted by authority, and is used in such phrases as penitentiam agere or facere, it has been necessary in the translation of the De Penitentia to vary the English terms, and to use sometimes repentance, sometimes penance.
